content.title: Achalasia
content.summary: Primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by failed relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and absent esophageal peristalsis, causing progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids
key_points: Failed LES relaxation + absent esophageal peristalsis
Dysphagia to BOTH solids AND liquids from onset
Loss of inhibitory neurons (nitric oxide, VIP) in myenteric plexus
Barium swallow: bird's beak narrowing at GE junction, dilated esophagus
High-resolution manometry (HRM) is gold standard for diagnosis
Treatment: disrupt LES - pneumatic dilation, Heller myotomy, POEM
Rule out pseudoachalasia (GE junction tumor) in older patients with rapid onset

statement.text: Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax and loss of esophageal peristalsis. It results from degeneration of inhibitory neurons in the myenteric plexus. Patients present with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids. High-resolution manometry is diagnostic. Treatment aims to disrupt the LES through pneumatic dilation, Heller myotomy, or POEM.
statement.formal: Achalasia = Elevated IRP (>15 mmHg) + Absent peristalsis (100% failed) on HRM

explanation.intuition: The esophagus pushes food toward the stomach through peristalsis. At the bottom, the LES must open to let food through. In achalasia, the nerves that tell the LES to relax are destroyed, so the gate stays closed. Food backs up, stretching the esophagus while the narrow LES creates a bottleneck.
explanation.key_insight: Dysphagia to both solids AND liquids from the beginning distinguishes achalasia (motility) from mechanical obstruction (stricture, cancer) which starts with solids. Treatment doesn't cure but palliates by breaking the dysfunctional LES.
explanation.technical_details: HRM defines 3 subtypes: Type I (classic), Type II (panesophageal pressurization, best response), Type III (spastic, worst prognosis). Chicago Classification v4.0 criteria: IRP >15 mmHg AND 100% failed peristalsis.

definitions_glossary.achalasia: Primary esophageal motility disorder with failed LES relaxation and absent peristalsis
definitions_glossary.lower_esophageal_sphincter: Muscular ring at GE junction that prevents reflux and must relax for swallowing
definitions_glossary.myenteric_plexus: Nerve network between muscle layers controlling esophageal motility
definitions_glossary.integrated_relaxation_pressure: IRP - manometric measure of LES relaxation; elevated in achalasia
definitions_glossary.birds_beak: Characteristic narrowing at GE junction on barium swallow
definitions_glossary.pneumatic_dilation: Balloon inflation to tear LES muscle fibers
definitions_glossary.heller_myotomy: Surgical division of LES muscle fibers
definitions_glossary.poem: Peroral endoscopic myotomy - endoscopic LES division
definitions_glossary.pseudoachalasia: Achalasia-like presentation from GE junction malignancy
definitions_glossary.chicago_classification: Standard system for esophageal motility disorders

pathophysiology.mechanism: Degeneration of inhibitory neurons (NO, VIP) in myenteric plexus leads to unopposed LES contraction and lost peristalsis. Progressive esophageal dilation occurs.

clinical.dysphagia: Progressive, BOTH solids AND liquids from onset

tests.endoscopy: Dilated esophagus, retained food, tight LES

definition.@value: Primary esophageal motility disorder with failed LES relaxation and absent peristalsis

clinical_pearls: Dysphagia to solids AND liquids from start = motility disorder
Bird's beak classic but HRM is gold standard
Type II has best treatment response
Older patient with rapid onset = pseudoachalasia
common_misconceptions: Achalasia starts with solids then liquids (false)

sources.source: Sleisenger and Fordtran's GI Disease, 11th ed. 2021
